<target_code>
Here is the code of send_all:
```c
static void
send_all (MHD_socket sock,
          const char *buf,
          size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  make_blocking (sock);
  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
    ret = send (sock,
                &buf[off],
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
                len - off,
#else  /* Native W32 */
                (int) (len - off),
#endif /* Native W32 */
                0);
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
      break;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The only pointer parameter is declared as const (const char *buf) and the code takes &buf[off], which is a pointer to const char — there are no local non-const pointer variables or pointer assignments that drop const qualification. The call to send is passed a pointer-to-const; on typical platforms send is declared to accept a const-qualified buffer parameter (const void * or const char *), so no const is discarded here. No other pointers appear in this function (make_blocking and MHD_socket are not pointer variables in this code). Therefore there are no places in this function that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
